Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Investigations of Quantum Fluctuation Relations Using Superconducting Qubits
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Abstract
In the last two decades, the development of nonequilibrium work fluctuation theorems has yielded new tools for the estimation of free energy differences in molecular systems, shed light on how microscopic systems exchange energy with their environment, and provided a deeper understanding of the nature of the second law of thermodynamics. However, while relations like the Jarzynski equality have been verified experimentally in the classical limit, they remain to be tested in the quantum regime. The experiments conducted in this project, which is supported by an award from the Division of Materials Research's Materials World Network, will utilize state-of-the-art superconducting microwave resonators and superconducting qubits to perform the first systematic investigations of fluctuation theorems in the quantum regime. The project will also provide the first experiments to probe the quantum mechanical nature of work, which has only recently been elucidated theoretically. Moreover, through close collaboration with theorists from the University of Campinas (Campinas, Brazil) and The Sao Carlos Institute of Physics (Sao Carlos, Brazil), it will provide fundamental insight into the nature of dissipation at the nanoscale and the modeling of open quantum systems, most notably in application to nonequilibrium fluctuation theorems, which remains an open theoretical question. This research will support the training of one graduate student and one postdoc in cutting-edge technologies for exploring quantum physics at the nanoscale, including fabrication techniques and low-noise measurement of superconducting devices at ultra-low temperatures; it will provide training to students in advanced theoretical techniques in quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics, including the modeling of open quantum systems and nonequilibrium fluctuation theorems; and it will foster an international collaboration, consisting not only of direct collaborative research but also research student exchange and development of topical, student-oriented research tutorials.

Non-Technical Abstract
In the last two decades, important advances have been made in our understanding of how systems at the micro and nanoscale exchange energy with the environment in which they are inevitably embedded. At the forefront of these advances has been the development of a new series of precise mathematical relationships between certain thermodynamic quantities - e.g. between the work that can be extracted from a system and the energy of the same system. These developments are important both from a fundamental perspective and an applied one. For example, these relations have refined our understanding of the second law of thermodynamics and irreversibility (i.e. the arrow of time); at the same time, they have provided greater insight into the limitations placed on the efficiency of machines at the smallest scale, a question of paramount importance as technology continues to be scaled down in size. Crucially, while these new relationships have been tested and utilized in a wide range of classical micro and nanoscale systems, their experimental verification in quantum systems remains an open challenge. The experiments conducted in this international collaborative project will utilize state-of-the-art superconducting circuitry to perform the first systematic investigations to meet this challenge. The broader impacts of this work are multifold: the research will provide fundamental insight into the nature of work and energy dissipation in quantum systems, which is of direct importance for understanding the potential of burgeoning quantum and hybrid-quantum technologies - such as quantum-assisted sensing and quantum information; it will support the training and education of one graduate student and one postdoc in cutting-edge techniques and topics in quantum nanoscale physics; and it will foster an international collaboration that promotes research student exchange and the general education of students in these advanced, contemporary topics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this Materials World Network project was to advance the experimental and theoretical study of quantum fluctuation theorems.  These theorems are the quantum mechanical counterpart of new statistical relations that have been developed over the past two decades and have yielded new tools for characterizing the properties of molecular systems, shed light on how microscopic systems exchange energy with their environment, and provided a deeper understanding of the nature of the second law of thermodynamics. While such theorems have been tested successfully in many classical contexts, the extension of such studies to quantum systems has just begun, and has direct relevance to topics in quantum information, quantum-enabled technologies, and the thermodynamics of quantum machines.   

            Under DMR-1312421, the LaHaye group and theory collaborators from the University of Campinas and Sao Carlos Institute of Physics proposed, analyzed, and began the experimental development of a new method for studying quantum fluctuation theorems using superconducting quantum circuitry.  The circuitry is composed of a superconducting quantum bit (qubit) and superconducting microwave cavity integrated together on a silicon wafer using standard nano- and microfabrication techniques.  Importantly, it is similar in design to the state-of-the-art systems that are being developed for use in solid-state quantum processing architectures. Thus, it provides a high degree of control and exquisite sensitivity for manipulating and measuring quantum circuit properties, making it an ideal platform for investigating the physical underpinnings of quantum fluctuation theorems, as well as related physics, including the efficiency of quantum heat engines, and thermodynamic aspects of quantum information. 

            Several important outcomes constitute the intellectual merit of this work.  First, the LaHaye group and collaborators developed the theory for a feasible experimental protocol for implementing tests of the important physical principles behind quantum fluctuation theorems, which provides experimentalists with an approach that is complimentary to recently proposed alternative measurement schemes and which also has implications for a broad range of topics including foundational issues in quantum mechanics, quantum thermodynamics, and quantum field theory.  This work was published in a peer-reviewed journal and presented in multiple research seminars, conference presentations, and poster sessions.  Second, the theoretical work has stimulated ongoing efforts by LaHaye and his collaborators to utilize the proposed system for investigations of quantum thermodynamics and connections to quantum information, including quantum heat engines.  Finally, the LaHaye group has developed new quantum circuitry that is of direct relevance to a broad range of experimental research efforts at the frontiers of quantum physics, including quantum thermodynamics, superconducting quantum computing, mechanical quantum systems,  and hybrid quantum systems.  Aspects of this outcome were also disseminated to the scientific community through peer-reviewed journal articles and many lectures, seminars, and poster presentations.

            This research also had several broader impacts.   First, this project provided opportunities for the training of one graduate student and one postdoc in topics and laboratory techniques that are of direct relevance to careers across the spectrum in science, engineering and tech fields. This includes training in nanofabrication, sensitive measurement techniques, microwave design and measurement, finite-element modelling, superconducting systems, cryogenics, the physics and measurement of quantum devices, and quantum information. The project also provided these same individuals with other valuable professional experiences, including participation in an international collaboration, the development of professional contacts in the scientific community, and opportunities in public communication and scientific writing. Second, the project provided opportunities for two undergraduate students to learn important laboratory techniques such as analog circuit design and mechanical design.  As well, it gave these students exposure to contemporary research topics in physics through participation in journal club sessions and through informal study of topics like superconductivity, superconducting devices, and circuit quantum electrodynamics. Finally, this work provided many opportunities for engagement with students (both undergraduate and graduate), researchers, and educators (including high school physics teachers) in the form of lectures and tutorials presented by LaHaye and his collaborators  on contemporary topics in quantum physics research.  In fact, the collaboration is continuing its engagement in educational activities beyond the duration of the project, with a new short course for graduate students to be offered at the University of Campinas in March 2017.
